messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 15, 2017 - February 21, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-02-23T22:55:09Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-02-15T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-02-21T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170223-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.    No CMEs traveling with a speed over 500km/s were observed in the available coronagraph imagery.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-02-17T03:00Z-12:00Z, 2017-02-17T15:00Z-18:00Z, 2017-02-17T21:00Z to 2017-02-18T06:00Z, and 2017-02-22T00:00Z-03:00Z.  The values of Kp=4 at the beginning of the reporting period were associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-02-16. The solar wind speed reached values of >600 km/s on 2017-02-19.  

The IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments at STEREO A detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-02-19.  The solar wind speed reached values >600 km/s on 2017-02-20.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-02-22T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-02-28T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the next reporting period.  Active region 12638 on the Earth's facing side may be capable of producing some low classification flares and CMEs.  The geomagnetic activity is expected to be enhanced for the upcoming reporting due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-02-23.  Solar wind speeds are currently detected by DSCOVR at L1 to be around >600km/s on 2017-02-23.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 08, 2017 - February 14, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-02-15T23:24:38Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-02-08T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-02-14T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170215-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  There were 1 C-type CME that was non-Earth directed (see details below).   


Geomagnetic activity was at low levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.


The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES exceeded 10^5 pfu on 2017-02-08T15:15Z after first exceeding the threshold on 2017-02-01T15:00Z (see notification 20170201-AL-001). The flux level has been on a declining trend since then and remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the remainder of the reporting period.


The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 


Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been small this week. 


##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  


CMEs (>500 km/s):


Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-02-10T13:48Z     ~594            C               148/18                10                          SOHO                              
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-02-15T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-02-21T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be very low for the upcoming week.  The active regions visible on the solar surface appear to have low magnetic complexity hence the probability for flares and coronal mass ejections is really low.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be slightly enhanced due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2017-02-16.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 01, 2017 - February 07, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-02-08T21:18:22Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-02-01T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-02-07T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170208-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period.  No CMEs traveling with a speed over 500km/s were observed in the available coronagraph imagery.  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-02-01T00:00Z-03:00Z, 2017-02-01T15:00Z-18:00Z, 2017-02-01T21:00Z-24:00Z.  This minor enhancement of geomagnetic activity was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-01-30.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-02-01T15:00Z, and remained elevated during the entire reporting period crossing the threshold several times.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated to the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20170201-AL-001, 20170201-AL-002, 20170203-AL-001, 20170205-AL-001, 20170207-AL-001).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-02-08T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-02-14T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be very low for the upcoming week.  The active regions visible on the solar surface appear to have low magnetic complexity hence the probability for flares and coronal mass ejections is really low.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be slightly enhanced for the beginning of the next reporting period due to the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream around late 2017-02-08.  


## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-02-07T16:07:14Z
## Message ID: 20170207-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above and around 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-02-01T15:00Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2017-01-30T11:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-02-01T15:00:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )

##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-02-05T16:16:00Z
## Message ID: 20170205-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux continues to be around 70-80% of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-02-01T15:00Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2017-01-30T11:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-02-01T15:00:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for January 25, 2017 - January 31, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-02-02T01:01:34Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-01-25T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-01-31T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170202-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very low levels during this reporting period. No CMEs faster than 500 km/s were detected in the coronagraph imagery.  

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-01-31T21:00Z to 2017-02-01T03:00Z.  This minor enhancement of geomagnetic activity is associated with a coronal hole high speed stream arrival detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-01-30.  Solar wind speed reached >750 km/s on 2017-01-31.  Previously, there was a smaller coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-02-26.  Solar wind speed reached values of >650km/s around 2017-01-27.  

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected arrivals of coronal holes high speed streams on 2017-01-28 and 2017-01-31.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. However, the flux levels became elevated and crossed the threshold around 2017-02-01T15:00Z due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above.   

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low during this reporting period.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):
Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-02-01T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-02-07T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be very low for the upcoming week.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be enhanced for the beginning of the next reporting period due to the arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream on 2017-01-30.  Currently, the > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES is above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-02-01T15:00Z. The geomagnetic Kp index has been Kp=5 for the synoptic periods of 2017-02-01T15:00Z-18:00Z and 2017-02-01T21:00Z-24:00Z.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-02-01T15:48:57Z
## Message ID: 20170201-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-02-01T15:00Z. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by  high speed stream starting at 2017-01-30T11:30Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-02-01T15:00:00-RBE-001.
